|url=https://variety.com/2022/awards/news/oscars-will-smith-consequences-chris-rock-1235228010/ |work=Variety |access-date=2022-04-20}} ===Refusals of the award=== Some winners critical of the Academy Awards have boycotted the ceremonies and refused to accept their Oscars. The first to do so was screenwriter [[Dudley Nichols]] (Best Writing in 1935 for ''[[The Informer (1935 film)|The Informer]]''). Nichols boycotted the [[8th Academy Awards]] ceremony because of conflicts between the Academy and the Writers' Guild.{{cite web |url=http://www.biography.com/oscars/oscars_didyouknow.jsp |title=The Oscars Did You Know? |access-date=June 18, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090623000022/http://www.biography.com/oscars/oscars_didyouknow.jsp |archive-date=June 23, 2009 |url-status=live}} Nichols eventually accepted the 1935 award three years later, at the 1938 ceremony. Nichols was nominated for three further Academy Awards during his career. [[George C. Scott]] became the second person to refuse his award (Best Actor in 1970 for ''[[Patton (film)|Patton]]'') at the [[43rd Academy Awards]] ceremony. Scott described it as a "meat parade," saying, "I don't want any part of it."{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/obituaries/455563.stm |work=BBC News |title=George C Scott: The man who refused an Oscar |date=September 23, 1999 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311095900/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/obituaries/455563.stm |archive-date=March 11, 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,904789,00.html |magazine=Time |title=Show Business: Meat Parade |date=March 8, 1971 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221203341/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0%2C9171%2C904789%2C00.html |archive-date=December 21, 2008}}{{cite web |url=http://www.biography.com/oscars/oscars_didyouknow.jsp |title=Fast Facts – Did You Know? |publisher=Biography.com |date=May 16, 1929 |access-date=February 6, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100210075430/http://www.biography.com/oscars/oscars_didyouknow.jsp |archive-date=February 10, 2010 |url-status=live}} The third person to refuse the award was [[Marlon Brando]], who refused his award (Best Actor for 1972's ''[[The Godfather]]''), citing the film industry's discrimination and mistreatment of [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]]. At the [[45th Academy Awards]] ceremony, Brando asked actress and [[civil rights activist]] [[Sacheen Littlefeather]] to read a 15-page speech in his place, detailing his criticisms, for which there was [[booing]] and [[cheering]] by the audience.{{Citation |last=Oscars |title=Marlon Brando's Oscar win for " The Godfather" |date=October 2, 2008 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2QUacU0I4yU |access-date=February 25, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110217152537/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2QUacU0I4yU |archive-date=February 17, 2011 |url-status=live}} ===Disqualifications=== Six films have had nominations revoked before the official award ceremony:{{cite news |url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/73722/8-oscar-nominations-were-revoked |title=9 Oscar Nominations That Were Revoked |last=Obias |first=Rudie |website=mentalfloss.com |publisher=Mental Floss |date=February 23, 2019 |access-date=October 14, 2019 |archive-date=November 16, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201116212356/https://www.mentalfloss.com/article/73722/8-oscar-nominations-were-revoked |url-status=live}} * ''[[The Circus (1928 film)|The Circus]]'' (1928) – The film was voluntarily removed by the Academy from competitive categories, to award [[Charlie Chaplin]] a special award. * ''[[Hondo (film)|Hondo]]'' (1953) – Removed from the Best Story ballot after letters from the producer and nominee questioned its inclusion in the category. * ''[[High Society (1955 film)|High Society]]'' (1955) – Withdrawn from screenwriting ballot after being mistaken for the [[High Society (1956 film)|1956 movie]] of the same title. * ''[[The Godfather]]'' (1972) – Initially nominated for eleven awards, its nomination for Best Original Score was revoked after it was discovered that its main theme was very similar to music that [[Nino Rota|the score's composer]] had written for an earlier film. None of its other nominations were revoked, and it received three Oscars, including Best Picture. * ''[[A Place in the World (film)|A Place in the World]]'' (1992) – Removed from the Best Foreign Language Film ballot after it was discovered that the country which submitted the film exercised insufficient artistic control. * ''[[Alone Yet Not Alone]]'' (2014) – The film's title song, "Alone Yet Not Alone," was removed from the Best Original Song ballot after [[Bruce Broughton]] was found to have improperly contacted other members of the academy's musical branch; this was the first time that a film was removed from a ballot for ethical reasons. One film was disqualified after winning the award, and had the winner return the Oscar: * ''[[Young Americans (1967 film)|Young Americans]]'' (1969) – Initially won the award for Best Documentary Feature, but was later revoked after it was revealed that it had opened theatrically prior to the eligibility period. One film had its nomination revoked after the award ceremony when it had not won the Oscar: * ''[[Tuba Atlantic]]'' (2011) – Its nomination for Best Live Action Short Film was revoked when it was discovered that the film had aired on television in 2010, before its theatrical release. ==Associated events== {{Unreferenced section|date=March 2021}} The following events are closely associated with the annual Academy Awards: * [[British Academy Film Awards|BAFTA Awards]] * [[César Award]]s * [[David di Donatello Awards]] * [[Goya Award]]s * Nominees luncheon * [[Governors Awards]] * The 25th [[Independent Spirit Awards]] (2010), usually held in [[Santa Monica, California|Santa Monica]], California the Saturday before the Oscars, marked the first time it was moved to a Friday and a change of venue to [[L.A. Live]] * The annual "Night Before," traditionally held at [[the Beverly Hills Hotel]], begun in 2002 and generally known as ''the ''party of the season, benefits the [[Motion Picture & Television Fund]], which operates a retirement home for SAG actors in the [[San Fernando Valley]] * [[Elton John AIDS Foundation Academy Award Party]] airs the awards live at the nearby [[Pacific Design Center]] * The Governors Ball is the Academy's official after-party, including dinner (until 2011), and is adjacent to the awards-presentation venue * The ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' after-party, historically at the former Morton's restaurant, has been at the [[Sunset Tower]] since 2009 * [[Ariel Award]] in Mexico ==Presenter and performer gifts== It has become a tradition to give out gift bags to the presenters and performers at the Oscars. In recent years, these gifts have also been extended to award nominees and winners.{{cite web |last=Valenti |first=Catherine |title=No Oscar? How About a Gift Bag? |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Business/story?id=86683 |work=ABC News |access-date=March 11, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140425162335/http://abcnews.go.com/Business/story?id=86683 |archive-date=April 25, 2014}} The value of each of these gift bags can reach into the tens of thousands of dollars. In 2014, the value was reported to be as high as US$80,000.{{cite news |last=Peterson |first=Kim |title=Oscars' gift bag has $80,000 worth of swag |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/oscars-gift-bag-has-80000-worth-of-swag/ |publisher=CBS News |access-date=March 11, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140305230143/http://www.cbsnews.com/news/oscars-gift-bag-has-80000-worth-of-swag/ |archive-date=March 5, 2014}} The value has risen to the point where the U.S. [[Internal Revenue Service]] issued a statement regarding the gifts and their taxable status.{{cite web |last=Staff |title=IRS Statement on Oscar Goodie Bags {{Short description|Championship game and trophy of the Canadian Football League}} {{For|a list of individual Grey Cups by year|List of Grey Cup champions}} {{Featured article}} {{Infobox sports award | name = Grey Cup | image = Grey Cup circa 2006.jpg | caption = Grey Cup in 2006 | alt = A trophy in the design of a silver cup affixed to a large, round wooden base. The base has silver plates attached to it engraved with the names of previous winners. | imagesize = 150px | first = [[1st Grey Cup|1909]] | country = Canada | givenfor = Winning the [[Canadian Football League]] championship | number = 108 | firstwinner = [[Toronto Varsity Blues football|Toronto Varsity Blues]] | mostwins = [[Toronto Argonauts]] (17) | mostrecent = [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]] (12th title) | url = {{URL|cfl.ca}} }}
The '''Grey Cup''' ({{lang-fr|Coupe Grey}}) is both the championship game of the [[Canadian Football League]] (CFL) and the trophy awarded to the victorious team playing in the namesake championship of professional [[Canadian football]]. The game is contested between the winners of the CFL's [[East Division (CFL)|East]] and [[West Division (CFL)|West]] Divisional playoffs and is one of [[Canadian television]]'s largest annual sporting events. The [[Toronto Argonauts]] have the most Grey Cup wins (17) since its introduction in 1909, while the [[Edmonton Elks]] (formerly the Edmonton Eskimos) have the most Grey Cup wins (11) since the merger in 1958. The latest, the [[108th Grey Cup]], took place in [[Hamilton, Ontario]], on December 12, 2021, when the [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]] defeated the [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] 33–25 in overtime.
The Grey Cup game is Canada's largest annual sports and television event, regularly drawing a Canadian viewing audience of about 4 million.<ref name="Houston">{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20061220.wsptcfl20/TPStory/Sports/columnists |title=Grey Cup moves to TSN in new deal |access-date=2007-06-07 |last=Houston |first=William |date=December 20, 2006 |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930064843/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20061220.wsptcfl20/TPStory/Sports/columnists |archive-date=September 30, 2007 }}</ref><ref name="Houston 2006-11-20">{{cite news|url=http://www.globesports.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20061120.wspttruth20/GSStory/GlobeSportsFootball/home|title=Minor rise in Grey Cup ratings good for CBC|access-date=2006-12-03|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=2006-11-20|author=William Houston}}</ref> Two awards are given for play in the game, [[Grey Cup Most Valuable Player|Most Valuable Player]] and the [[Dick Suderman Trophy]] as most valuable Canadian player.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/greycup/mvp_top.html |title=MVP and Top Canadians|access-date=2008-01-20 |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]}}</ref> As a member of the [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]], [[Andrew Harris (Canadian football)|Andrew Harris]] is the only player to win both the Grey Cup's Most Valuable Canadian and Most Valuable Player the same year, which he did in 2019.
The trophy was commissioned in 1909 by [[Albert Grey, 4th Earl Grey|The Earl Grey]], then [[Governor General of Canada|Canada's governor general]], who originally hoped to donate it for the country's [[senior hockey|senior amateur hockey]] championship. After the [[Allan Cup]] was later donated for that purpose, Grey instead made his trophy available as the "[[Canadian Dominion Football Championship]]" (national championship) of Canadian football. The trophy has a silver [[chalice]] attached to a large base on which the names of all winning teams, players and executives are engraved. The Grey Cup has been broken on several occasions, stolen twice, and held for ransom. It survived a 1947 fire that destroyed numerous artifacts housed in the same building.
The Grey Cup was first won by the [[University of Toronto Varsity Blues]]. Play was suspended from 1916 to 1918 due to the [[World War I|First World War]] and in 1919 due to a rules dispute. The game has typically been contested in an east-versus-west format since the 1920s. The game was always played on a Saturday until 1968, but since 1969 (except for 1970) has always been on a Sunday. Held in late November (in some years in early December, most recently in 2021), and mostly in outdoor stadiums, the Grey Cup has been played in inclement weather at times, including the 1950 "[[38th Grey Cup|Mud Bowl]]", in which a player reportedly came close to drowning in a puddle, then the 1962 "[[50th Grey Cup|Fog Bowl]]", when the final minutes of the game had to be postponed to the following day due to a heavy fog, and the 1977 "[[65th Grey Cup|Ice Bowl]]", contested on the frozen-over artificial turf at [[Montreal]]'s [[Olympic Stadium (Montreal)|Olympic Stadium]]. Most recently, in the [[105th Grey Cup|2017 game]] snow fell, at times heavily, throughout the game.
The then-Edmonton Eskimos formed the Grey Cup's longest [[dynasty (sports)|dynasty]], winning five consecutive championships from 1978 to 1982. Competition for the trophy has been exclusively between Canadian teams, except for a three-year period from 1993 to 1995, when an expansion of the CFL south into the United States resulted in the [[Baltimore Stallions]] winning the 1995 championship and taking the Grey Cup south of the border for the only time in its history.
==History==
===National championships before 1909=== Serious efforts to organize a national governing body and eventually a Dominion championship for what at that time was still a game called and practically identical to [[rugby union]] began in the early 1880s, culminating in the creation of the Canadian Rugby Union in 1891 and the first CRU-recognized national championship the following year. After that, [[Football Canada#Champions prior to 1909|national championship games]] were held every year prior to the creation of the Grey Cup except 1899, 1903 and 1904.
===Creation and early years (1909–1921)=== [[File:Albert Grey.jpg|thumb|right|upright|The Earl Grey donated the Grey Cup in 1909.|alt=Upper body of a bald man with a large moustache. He is in a military uniform with several medals pinned to his left chest.]] While the [[Stanley Cup]] was created in 1893 as the Canadian amateur hockey championship, professional teams were openly competing for the trophy by 1907.<ref>{{harvnb|Diamond|Zweig|Duplacey|2003|p=19}}</ref> [[Albert Grey, 4th Earl Grey]], the [[Governor General of Canada]], planned to donate a new trophy to serve as the senior amateur championship; however, [[H. Montagu Allan|Sir Montague Allan]] donated the [[Allan Cup]] before he could finalize his plans. Grey instead offered an award for the Canadian amateur rugby football championship beginning in 1909.<ref name="Kelly11">{{harvnb|Kelly|1999|p=11}}</ref> He initially failed to follow through on his offer; the trophy was not ordered until two weeks prior to the first championship game.<ref name="CFHOF">{{citation |url=http://cfhof.ca/history-of-the-grey-cup/ |title=History of the Grey Cup |publisher=Canadian Football Hall of Fame and Museum |access-date=2012-06-27}}</ref>
The [[1st Grey Cup|first Grey Cup]] game was held on December 4, 1909, between two Toronto clubs: the [[Toronto Varsity Blues|University of Toronto Varsity Blues]] defeated the [[Toronto Parkdale|Parkdale Canoe Club]] 26–6 before 3,800 fans.<ref name="Theile13">{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=13}}</ref> The trophy was not ready for presentation following the game, and the Varsity Blues did not receive it until March 1910.<ref name="CFHOF" /> They retained the trophy in the following two years, defeating the [[Hamilton Tigers (football)|Hamilton Tigers]] in [[2nd Grey Cup|1910]] and the [[Toronto Argonauts]] in [[3rd Grey Cup|1911]].<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|pp=15–16}}</ref> The University of Toronto failed to reach the [[4th Grey Cup|1912 Grey Cup]], which was won by the [[Hamilton Alerts]] over the Argonauts.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=17}}</ref> The Varsity Blues refused to hand over the trophy on the belief they could keep it until they were defeated in a title game. They kept the trophy until [[6th Grey Cup|1914]] when they were defeated by the Argonauts, who made the trophy available to subsequent champions.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=3}}</ref>
Canada's participation in [[World War I]] resulted in the cancellation of the championship from 1916 to 1918, during which time the Cup was forgotten. ''[[Montreal Gazette]]'' writer Bob Dunn claimed that the trophy was later rediscovered as "one of the family heirlooms" of an employee of the Toronto trust company where it had been sent for storage.<ref name="Theile4">{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=4}}</ref> The Grey Cup game was also cancelled in 1919 due to a lack of interest from the [[Interprovincial Rugby Football Union]] (IRFU) and the intercollegiate unions, along with rules conflicts between the [[Football Canada|Canadian Rugby Union]] (CRU) and the western union; Canada was still struggling in its recovery from the [[Spanish flu]] epidemic that occurred during the last months of World War I.<ref>{{citation |url=http://greycup.cfl.ca/page/grey-cup-history-timeline-1910 |title=Grey Cup History Timeline 1910 |publisher=Canadian Football League |access-date=2012-06-28 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819234629/http://greycup.cfl.ca/page/grey-cup-history-timeline-1910 |archive-date=2012-08-19 }}</ref> Competition finally resumed in 1920 with the [[8th Grey Cup]] game, won 16–3 by the Varsity Blues over the Argonauts. It was the University of Toronto's fourth, and final, championship.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=23}}</ref>
===Western participation (1922–1932)=== Competition for the Grey Cup was limited to member unions of the CRU, the champions of which petitioned the league body for the right to challenge for the national championship.<ref>{{citation |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mfAuAAAAIBAJ&pg=5175,5501187 |title=Canadian Rugby Union refuses to accept Regina's challenge |work=Ottawa Citizen |date=1936-12-04 |access-date=2012-08-12 |page=12}}</ref><ref name="BigStick">{{citation |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=D7BUAAAAIBAJ&pg=7450,330559 |title=Big-stick proposal offered |work=Regina Leader-Post |date=1957-03-02 |access-date=2012-08-12 |page=19}}</ref> The [[West Division (CFL)#Pre-1936|Western Canada Rugby Football Union]] (WCRFU) was formed in 1911, but the CRU did not come to a participation agreement with it until 1921, allowing the [[Edmonton Rugby Foot-ball Club|Edmonton Eskimos]] (no lineage to the [[Edmonton Elks|team that used that name]] 1949–2020) of the WCRFU to challenge.<ref name="1920Timeline">{{citation |url=http://greycup.cfl.ca/page/grey-cup-history-timeline-1920 |title=Grey Cup History Timeline 1920 |publisher=Canadian Football League |access-date=2012-08-12 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819234634/http://greycup.cfl.ca/page/grey-cup-history-timeline-1920 |archive-date=2012-08-19 }}</ref> Facing the Argonauts in the [[9th Grey Cup]], the Eskimos became the first western team{{snd}}and the first from outside Toronto or Hamilton{{snd}}to compete for the trophy.<ref name="CFL9thGC">{{citation |url=http://greycup.cfl.ca/1921gc |title=Grey Cup 1921 |publisher=Canadian Football League |access-date=2012-07-01 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512150742/http://greycup.cfl.ca/1921gc |archive-date=2012-05-12 }}</ref> The Argonauts entered the game with an undefeated record, having outscored their opposition 226 to 55 during the season. They dominated Edmonton, recording the first [[shutout]] in Grey Cup history with a 23–0 victory.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=24}}</ref> Multi-sport star [[Lionel Conacher]] was Toronto's top player, scoring 15 of his team's points before leaving the game after the third quarter to join his hockey team for their game.<ref name="CFL9thGC" /> The same Edmonton team (renamed as Edmonton Elks) challenged for the trophy again in [[10th Grey Cup|1922]], but lost 13–1 to their eastern opposition, the [[Queen's Golden Gaels|Queen's University Golden Gaels]]. For Queen's, it was the first of three consecutive titles.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=27}}</ref>
Western teams continued to vie for the trophy, but were consistently outclassed for several years. Eastern teams and critics felt the quality of the western game was inferior to theirs, and when Queen's defeated the [[Regina Rugby Club]] 54–0 in the [[11th Grey Cup|1923 final]], the critics felt they deliberately ran up the score to prove that point.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=28}}</ref> Regina was western Canada's dominant team, appearing in the Grey Cup on six occasions between 1928 and 1934, but lost to their eastern opponents each time.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=37}}</ref> Regina helped revolutionize Canadian football in [[17th Grey Cup|1929]], however, as they attempted the first [[forward pass]] in Grey Cup history.<ref name="1920Timeline" /> The Winnipeg 'Pegs (now the [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers|Blue Bombers]]) became the first western Grey Cup champion in [[23rd Grey Cup|1935]] when they defeated the Hamilton Tigers, 18–12.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=50}}</ref> While the Grey Cup was slow to achieve national popularity,<ref name="CanEncyFogBowl">{{citation |last=Marsh |first=James H. |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/featured/fog-bowl |title=Fog Bowl |publisher=Historica-Dominion Institute |access-date=2012-08-19}}</ref> the advent of the east versus west format helped make the game the nation's largest sporting event.<ref>{{citation |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tYotAAAAIBAJ&pg=3200,5418901 |title=That November Madness |work=Montreal Gazette |date=1959-11-28 |access-date=2012-08-14 |page=6}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ru1kAAAAIBAJ&pg=1799,4438940 |title=1960 Grey Cup trip recalls first Eskimo venture in 1921 |work=Edmonton Journal |date=1960-11-23 |access-date=2012-08-14 |page=39}}</ref>
===Progress towards professionalism (1933–1956)=== [[File:Grey Cup VPL 43916 (15892818281).jpg|thumb|left|175px|Woman poses with Grey Cup in 1955.]] As the quality of senior football improved, university teams realized they were no longer able to compete on equal footing and withdrew from competition for the Grey Cup in 1933.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=47}}</ref> By 1938, only three unions continued to compete under the banner of the CRU: the IRFU (now commonly known as the Big Four) and the [[Ontario Rugby Football Union]] (ORFU) in the east, and the [[Western Interprovincial Football Union]] (WIFU) in the west.<ref name="Gazette1986History">{{citation |last=Bacon |first=Dick |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2pA0AAAAIBAJ&pg=1521,5496235 |title=From the mud bowl to the fog bowl, there's nothing quite like... The Grey Cup |work=Montreal Gazette |date=1986-11-29 |access-date=2012-07-01 |page=D1}}</ref> The CRU experimented with a two-game, total points series to determine the champion in [[28th Grey Cup|1940]]. The [[Ottawa Rough Riders]] won both games against Toronto's [[Toronto Balmy Beach Beachers|Balmy Beach]], 8–2 and 12–5. The Grey Cup returned to its one-game format the following year.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=60}}</ref>
Both the Big Four and WIFU suspended operations in 1942 due to the [[World War II|Second World War]].<ref name="Timeline1940s">{{citation |url=http://greycup.cfl.ca/page/grey-cup-history-timeline-1940 |title=Grey Cup History Timeline 1940 |publisher=Canadian Football League |access-date=2012-07-01 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120820235902/http://greycup.cfl.ca/page/grey-cup-history-timeline-1940 |archive-date=2012-08-20 }}</ref> Grey Cup play was expected to be suspended along with the unions; however, the military felt the game and sport would serve as a morale booster and organized teams at bases across the country.<ref name="Theile1997">{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=64}}</ref> For the following three years, Grey Cup competition was limited to military teams, and in the [[30th Grey Cup|1942 Grey Cup]], the [[Toronto RCAF Hurricanes]] defeated the [[Winnipeg RCAF Bombers]] 8–5 to become the first non-civilian team to win the national championship.<ref name="Theile1997" /> Two years later, the [[St. Hyacinthe–Donnacona Navy]] defeated the [[Hamilton Flying Wildcats]], 7–6; no Grey Cup championship since then has featured two eastern teams.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=68}}</ref> The conclusion of the war led to the reformation of civilian teams; the Big Four resumed play in 1945, and the WIFU the following year.<ref name="Timeline1940s" />
A push by the sport's organizers to adopt an increasingly professional attitude dominated the post-war period: poor field conditions, previously accepted as part of the game, resulted in numerous complaints against the CRU following the [[37th Grey Cup|1949]] and [[38th Grey Cup|1950]] Grey Cups.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=71}}</ref> Field conditions at Toronto's [[Varsity Stadium]] were so poor in 1950 that the game has since gained infamy as the "Mud Bowl".<ref name="MudBowl60th">{{citation |url=http://www.argonauts.ca/article/60-years-later-mud-bowl |title=60 years later: Mud Bowl |publisher=Toronto Argonauts Football Club |date=2010-11-25 |access-date=2012-07-01 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101212092124/http://argonauts.ca/article/60-years-later-mud-bowl |archive-date=2010-12-12 }}</ref> Deep ruts in the field and poor weather in the days leading up to the game resulted in a sloppy field covered in large puddles of water. The game also gained notoriety for the near drowning of Winnipeg's [[Buddy Tinsley]], who was found face down in a large puddle, apparently unconscious. Tinsley later said that he had not lost consciousness, but his leg had gone numb from a hard hit to a preexisting injury.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=83}}</ref> Toronto won the game 13–0, the last time a team has been shut out in a Grey Cup game.<ref name="MudBowl60th" />
[[File:1956 Grey Cup victory.jpg|thumb|[[Don Getty]], future [[Premier of Alberta]], celebrates with the Grey Cup after the Eskimos' 1956 championship.|alt=A man with short hair in a white football uniform drinks out of a large silver cup.]] The ORFU, the last purely amateur union competing for the Grey Cup, withdrew from Cup competition in 1954. Although the Big Four and WIFU champions had faced each other in the Grey Cup final since 1945, the ORFU's withdrawal left the IRFU and WIFU unchallenged as Canada's top football unions.<ref name="Timeline1950s">{{citation|url=http://greycup.cfl.ca/page/grey-cup-history-timeline-1950 |title=Grey Cup History Timeline 1950 |publisher=Canadian Football League |access-date=2012-07-01 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120820235902/http://greycup.cfl.ca/page/grey-cup-history-timeline-1950 |archive-date=2012-08-20 }}</ref> The Eskimos faced the [[Montreal Alouettes]] in three consecutive Grey Cups in the mid-1950s, winning all three.<ref>{{citation |last=Jones |first=Terry |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Football/CFL/GreyCup/2005/11/25/1323064-sun.html |title=A matchup for the ages |work=Edmonton Sun |date=2005-11-25 |access-date=2012-07-02}}</ref> Edmonton's first title in 1954 ended in bizarre fashion after [[Jackie Parker]] scored a touchdown (converted by Bob Dean) from a fumble recovery late in the game that gave Edmonton a 26–25 lead. At the time in Canadian football, touchdowns were only worth 5 points. Parker's 90-yard fumble return was the longest in league history until Toronto's Cassius Vaughn returned a Calgary fumble 109 yards in the 2017 Grey Cup game which was won by Toronto. The 1954 game also marked the end of the amateur era as the top teams completed their transition to professional organizations.<ref name="Theile97">{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=97}}</ref>
As the 1950s wore on, the Big Four and WIFU distanced themselves from the CRU, forming the Canadian Football Council in 1956 to administer the game at the professional level.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=88}}</ref> Two years later, on January 18, 1958, the CFC withdrew from the CRU and the Big Four & WIFU merged into the [[Canadian Football League]] (CFL). The new league formally assumed control of the Grey Cup from the CRU.<ref>{{citation |last=Vickery |first=Al |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9xYvAAAAIBAJ&pg=7048%2C2776041 |title=Canadian football loop formed; takes over Grey Cup |work=Montreal Gazette |date=1958-01-18 |access-date=2012-07-01 |page=7}}</ref>
===Canadian Football League kicks off (1957–1969)=== In the CFL's initial seasons, the [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] were the league's dominant team, appearing in nine Grey Cups and winning four titles between 1957 and 1967.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=98}}</ref> The Winnipeg Blue Bombers opposed Hamilton on six of those occasions, winning four titles.<ref name="Gazette1986History" /> The two teams were involved in a series of bizarre incidents, the first occurring during the [[45th Grey Cup|1957 Grey Cup]].<ref name="Kelly118">{{harvnb|Kelly|1999|p=118}}</ref> Toronto-based lawyer and fan David Humphrey had talked his way past stadium security and had been allowed to watch the game from the sidelines.<ref name="HumphreyObit">{{citation |last=Hall |first=Joseph |url=https://www.thestar.com/article/636710 |title=David G. Humphrey, 83: Lawyer stepped into sports lore |work=Toronto Star |date=2009-05-20 |access-date=2012-07-02}}</ref> Ten minutes into the fourth quarter, Hamilton's [[Ray Bawel]] intercepted a pass and it appeared he would return the ball for a touchdown when Humphrey stuck his leg out and tripped Bawel as he ran up the sideline.<ref name="Kelly118" /> Unsure how to handle the situation as there was no rule designed to cover it, referee [[Paul Dojack]] invented one on the spot. He placed the ball half the distance to the Winnipeg goal line from the point Bawel was tripped.<ref name="ESZebras">{{citation |last=Jones |first=Terry |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Football/CFL/GreyCup/2004/06/10/493876.html |title=He's king of the zebras |work=Edmonton Sun |date=2004-06-10 |access-date=2012-07-02}}</ref> The incident did not affect the final score, as Hamilton won 32–7.<ref name="CBC2006GreatestGCs">{{citation |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/greycup/features/topmoments.html |title=Greatest Grey Cup moments |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=2006-11-03 |access-date=2012-07-02}}</ref> The league also created a new rule during the [[49th Grey Cup|1961 Grey Cup]] as it was the first in history to end regulation time in a tie: CFL Commissioner Sid Halter determined the teams would play an [[overtime (sports)|overtime]] period that consisted of two five-minute halves. That rule remained the CFL standard into the 2000s.<ref name="ESZebras" /> Winnipeg scored the lone touchdown in overtime to defeat Hamilton 21–14.<ref>{{citation |last=Friesen |first=Paul |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Football/CFL/GreyCup/2006/11/13/2339461.html |title=Top 10 greatest Grey Cups |work=Winnipeg Sun |date=2006-11-13 |access-date=2012-07-13}}</ref>
Winnipeg and Hamilton met again in 1962, the [[50th Grey Cup]], immortalized as the "Fog Bowl".<ref name="CBC2006GreatestGCs" /> The game was held at Toronto's [[Exhibition Stadium]], and began on Saturday, December 1, 1962. The fog rolled in early in the second quarter and became increasingly dense as the game progressed.<ref name="Kelly134">{{harvnb|Kelly|1999|p=134}}</ref> By the fourth quarter, the players were unable to see the sideline markers and the fans unable to see the play.<ref name="CBC2006GreatestGCs" /> The players were unable to see the ball in the air – kick returners listened for the sound of the ball hitting the ground – and the action was largely invisible to the television audience.<ref name="CanEncyFogBowl" /> With nine minutes and twenty-nine seconds remaining in the game and Winnipeg holding onto a 28–27 lead, officials made the unprecedented decision to suspend play until the next day.<ref name="Kelly134" /> Though the league feared that continuing fog on the morning of December 2 would force the complete abandonment of the game, it lifted in time for the contest to resume. Around 15,000 of the original 32,655 spectators watched Winnipeg win the Grey Cup without further scoring by either team.<ref>{{citation |last=Peacock |first=Jim |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=MoEuAAAAIBAJ&pg=6740%2C328067 |title=Fog-hit Grey Cup classic in Toronto nearly washed out as no contest |work=Montreal Gazette |date=1962-12-03 |access-date=2012-07-02 |page=1}}</ref> It was the first title game completed on a Sunday;<ref>{{citation |url=http://greycup.cfl.ca/page/grey-cup-history-timeline-1960 |title=Grey Cup History Timeline 1960 |publisher=Canadian Football League |access-date=2012-08-12 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120820235955/http://greycup.cfl.ca/page/grey-cup-history-timeline-1960 |archive-date=2012-08-20 }}</ref> the Grey Cup moved from its traditional Saturday start to Sunday in 1969; however, the game was played on a Saturday for the last time in 1970.<ref>{{citation |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4GlkAAAAIBAJ&pg=3276,1711652 |title=Montreal stadium selected for 1969 Grey Cup game |work=Calgary Herald |date=1968-06-07 |access-date=2012-08-10 |page=16}}</ref>
The Saskatchewan Roughriders won their first ever Grey Cup in [[54th Grey Cup|1966]] when they defeated the Ottawa Rough Riders 29–14 at Empire Stadium in Vancouver before 36,553 fans.
===Eskimos' dynasty (1970–1988)=== The Montreal Alouettes' [[58th Grey Cup|1970 Grey Cup]] championship, an upset win over the favoured [[Calgary Stampeders]], served as a morale booster for the city of Montreal, which was reeling in the aftermath of the [[October Crisis]].<ref name="Gazette1986History" /> The 1970s belonged to the Edmonton Eskimos, however, as they ended the decade as one of the most dominant teams in CFL history,<ref>{{harvnb|Kelly|1999|p=48}}</ref> reaching the Grey Cup nine times between 1973 and 1982.<ref name="GreyCupRecords">{{citation|url=https://www.cfl.ca/uploads/assets/CFL/PDF_Docs/2011/Grey_Cup_Record_Book_2011.pdf |title=Grey Cup record book, 2011 |publisher=Canadian Football League |year=2011 |access-date=2012-07-02 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419071354/http://www.cfl.ca/uploads/assets/CFL/PDF_Docs/2011/Grey_Cup_Record_Book_2011.pdf |archive-date=2012-04-19 }}</ref> The team competed in three consecutive finals early in the decade, losing to Ottawa in [[61st Grey Cup|1973]] and Montreal in [[62nd Grey Cup|1974]], before winning the franchise's fourth championship in [[63rd Grey Cup|1975]].<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|pp=135–139}}</ref> The 1975 championship was held in Calgary and was the first Grey Cup played on the [[Canadian Prairies]].<ref>{{citation|url=http://greycup.cfl.ca/page/grey-cup-history-timeline-1970 |title=Grey Cup History Timeline 1970 |publisher=Canadian Football League |access-date=2012-07-02 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120821000348/http://greycup.cfl.ca/page/grey-cup-history-timeline-1970 |archive-date=2012-08-21 }}</ref> A young woman infamously [[Streaking|streaked]] across the field during the national anthem despite frigid temperatures well below freezing.<ref>{{citation |url=https://nationalpost.com/news/toronto/story.html?id=42ac1e6d-6352-4ab8-9a67-441670f85b39&k=48495 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130130094452/http://www.nationalpost.com/news/toronto/story.html?id=42ac1e6d-6352-4ab8-9a67-441670f85b39&k=48495 |url-status=dead |archive-date=2013-01-30 |title=Dealing with the naked truth |work=National Post |access-date=2012-07-02 }}</ref> The only time the Eskimos did not reach the Grey Cup final during this span was in [[64th Grey Cup|1976]], when the Saskatchewan Roughriders met the Ottawa Rough Riders, in the final all-"Roughriders" Grey Cup game. Both teams fought a see-saw battle, which was decided in the dying seconds of the game when Ottawa quarterback [[Tom Clements]] threw to [[Tony Gabriel]], which stood out as the winning touchdown, 23–20. The [[65th Grey Cup|1977 Grey Cup]] was the first held at [[Olympic Stadium]] in Montreal, contested by the home town Alouettes and the Eskimos in front of a record crowd of 68,318.<ref name="GreyCupRecords" /> The game became known as the "Ice Bowl", as low temperatures froze snow on the field that had been melted by groundskeepers with salt, making the [[artificial turf]] extremely slippery. The Alouettes adapted to the field conditions by affixing staples to the soles of their shoes, improving their traction, and won the game by a 41–6 score.<ref name="Gazette1986History" />
Upset at losing the 1977 game under poor weather conditions, the Eskimos hoped for a rematch with Montreal in [[66th Grey Cup|1978]].<ref>{{harvnb|Kelly|1999|p=60}}</ref> Both teams reached the final game, which Edmonton won 20–13. It was the first of five consecutive championships, a streak that remains unmatched in the history of the Grey Cup.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=147}}</ref> The Eskimos' [[Dynasty (sports)|dynasty]] dominated the league, losing a total of only six games during the three seasons from 1979 to 1981.<ref>{{harvnb|Kelly|1999|p=71}}</ref> The [[69th Grey Cup|1981 Grey Cup]] was expected to be yet another easy win for Edmonton, who posted a 14–1–1 record during the season and were considered overwhelming favourites against the surprise Eastern champions, the 5–11 Ottawa Rough Riders.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=155}}</ref> The first half did not go as Edmonton hoped, though, as Ottawa, led by rookie quarterback [[J.C. Watts]], emerged with a 20–1 lead. Quarterback [[Warren Moon]] led the Eskimos back in the second half, and with the game tied at 23, [[Dave Cutler (Canadian football)|Dave Cutler]] kicked the game-winning field goal with just three seconds remaining.<ref>{{citation |last=Bacon |first=Dick |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tUIwAAAAIBAJ&pg=1456%2C2076374 |title=Esks rally for record Grey Cup win |work=Montreal Gazette |date=1981-11-23 |access-date=2012-07-02 |page=33}}</ref>
Edmonton's championship run came to an end in [[71st Grey Cup|1983]] when they lost in the West Semi-Final game; the Argonauts defeated the [[BC Lions]] to win the championship that year, ending the team's 31-year Grey Cup title drought.<ref name="GreyCupRecords" /> Despite Toronto's win, the CFL felt that the overall quality of play in the East Division had deteriorated compared to that of the West. In 1986, it altered the playoff format to allow the first non-playoff team in one division to take the last playoff spot, but stay in their division if they had a better record. The consequences of the new rules were felt immediately, as the league gave a playoff spot to the Stampeders having a better record than the Alouettes, and decided the East Division Final would be a 2-game-total-point Final between the Toronto Argonauts and the Hamilton Tiger-Cats, who finished first and second, respectively. The crossover, if necessary, would begin in 1987. In financial difficulty, the loss of the playoff spot was disastrous for Montreal, which ceased operations one year later.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=162}}</ref> The crossover rule was eliminated and not revisited until a decade later due to Montreal's folding (ironically, the crossover rule returned with the Alouettes' revival). Reduced to eight teams, the CFL shifted Winnipeg to the East Division, making the [[76th Grey Cup|1988 Grey Cup]] between the Blue Bombers and Lions the first championship game between two [[Western Canada|western Canadian]] teams.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=173}}</ref>
===CFL USA (1989–1995)=== The [[77th Grey Cup|1989 Grey Cup]] is considered one of the finest games in Canadian football history:<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=176}}</ref><ref name="2006TenGreatest">{{citation |url=http://www.canada.com/cityguides/winnipeg/story.html?id=534dffdf-8cff-4698-b1db-6ed2ae6adb95 |title=10 greatest Grey Cups of all time |work=Vancouver Sun |date=2006-11-18 |access-date=2012-07-04 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304032125/http://www.canada.com/cityguides/winnipeg/story.html?id=534dffdf-8cff-4698-b1db-6ed2ae6adb95 |archive-date=2016-03-04 }}</ref> The Saskatchewan Roughriders won their second championship by defeating the Hamilton Tiger-Cats 43–40 in the highest scoring Grey Cup game of all-time.<ref name="GreyCupRecords" /> Saskatchewan kicker [[Dave Ridgway]]'s last-second field goal won the game and made him a legend in the prairie province.<ref>{{citation |last=Busby |first=Ian |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Football/CFL/GreyCup/2009/11/29/11970171-sun.html |title=Ridgway win in cards for kicker Congi? |publisher=Sun Media |date=2009-11-29 |access-date=2012-07-04 }}{{Dead link|date=July 2022 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Declining interest in the CFL during the 1990s left the league in financial difficulty. Hoping to restore the league's credibility with fans, a new ownership group featuring [[Bruce McNall]], hockey player [[Wayne Gretzky]] and actor [[John Candy]] purchased the Toronto Argonauts in 1991 and lured American college standout [[Raghib Ismail|Rocket Ismail]] to Canada with a four-year, $26.2 million contract which made him the highest paid player in football history at that time.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1060799.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018220542/https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1060799.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2016-10-18 |title=Ismail Signs $26.2 Million Deal to Rocket to Canada |work=The Washington Post |date=1991-04-21 |access-date=2012-07-04}}{{subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research|HighBeam]]}}</ref> The Argonauts reached the [[79th Grey Cup|1991 Grey Cup]] and defeated the Calgary Stampeders 36–21. With 261 all-purpose yards on the game, including a then-Grey Cup record 87-yard [[Kickoff (American football)|kickoff]] return for a touchdown, Ismail was named [[Grey Cup Most Valuable Player]].<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=184}}</ref>
The potential for the league to enter the American market was discussed in 1987 when operators of the defunct [[United States Football League]] approached the CFL about merging the two leagues.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-3811251.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309194824/https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-3811251.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2016-03-09 |title=New football league hope slim // CFL 'lukewarm' to merger with the defunct USFL |work=Chicago Sun-Times |date=1987-02-18 |access-date=2012-07-04}} {{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref> The league showed little interest at the time, but as it continued its decline, the CFL reevaluated its position. In 1992, the CFL announced that it would [[Canadian Football League in the United States|expand into the United States]]. The [[Sacramento Gold Miners]] joined the league and became the first American team eligible to win the Grey Cup.<ref>{{citation |last=Domowitch |first=Paul |title=CFL begins living the American dream |work=Philadelphia Daily News |date=1994-07-07 |page=66}}</ref> The league added three additional American teams in 1994 and two in 1995 (with one team folding), but the initiative failed in most markets, and by 1996, the CFL again operated exclusively within Canada.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=193}}</ref>
The lone successful American market was in Baltimore, home to the [[Baltimore Stallions|Stallions]]. The team averaged over 35,000 fans per game in its inaugural season, nearly double that of Toronto or Hamilton. They matched that success on the field by becoming the first American team to play in the Grey Cup.<ref>{{citation |last=Swardson |first=Anne |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-920317.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808120037/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-920317.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2014-08-08 |title=Canadian Football Unhorsed;Northerners Decry Threat by Baltimore Non-Colts to Run Off With Revered Grey Cup |work=The Washington Post |date=1994-11-22 |access-date=2012-07-04}}{{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref> The BC Lions kept the Grey Cup in Canada with a 26–23 victory in the [[82nd Grey Cup|1994 final]].<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=189}}</ref> Baltimore returned to the title game [[83rd Grey Cup|one year later]] and became the only American team to win the trophy by defeating the Calgary Stampeders, 37–20.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|p=191}}</ref> The [[Cleveland Browns relocation controversy|relocation]] of the [[National Football League]]'s [[Cleveland Browns]] to Baltimore (to become the [[Baltimore Ravens|Ravens]]) in 1996 caused the Stallions to seek a new city to avoid direct competition with an NFL team. The team moved to Montreal, forming the current incarnation of the Alouettes franchise and ending the CFL's excursion into the United States.<ref>{{citation |last=Klingaman |first=Mike |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2000-11-26/sports/0011260151_1_baltimore-stallions-grey-cup-stallions-won |title=Once, the Stallions rode high |work=The Baltimore Sun |date=2000-11-26 |access-date=2012-07-04}}</ref>
===Renaissance (1996–present)=== [[File:Anthony Calvillo game action, 93rd Grey Cup.jpg|thumb|right|Montreal Alouettes quarterback [[Anthony Calvillo]] looks down field with the ball during the [[2005 Grey Cup]] against the Edmonton Eskimos at [[BC Place Stadium]].|alt=The quarterback, holding the football, looks down field for a teammate to pass to while several of his teammates push up against four opposing players attempting to reach him.]] The league approached the [[84th Grey Cup|1996 Grey Cup]] in dire financial straits: the American expansion had been a failure, the 120-year-old Ottawa Rough Riders franchise ceased operations at the conclusion of the regular season,<ref name="BNLastGC">{{citation |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BN&p_theme=bn&p_action=search&p_text_direct-0=0EAF99A4152B2F63&p_field_direct-0=document_id |title=CFL Struggles into Grey Cup game |work=The Buffalo News |date=1996-11-23 |access-date=2012-07-06}}{{subscription required}}</ref> and out of the eight remaining teams, seven had lost money and two required direct assistance from the league to stay afloat. The Edmonton Eskimos could not afford to bring their players' families to the championship game.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-23366638.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140610060112/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-23366638.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2014-06-10 |title=Could today's game be the last Grey Cup? |work=The Columbian (Vancouver, WA)|date=1996-11-24 |access-date=2012-07-06}} {{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref> The ''[[Toronto Star]]'' echoed fears spoken by fans and media across the country when it asked if the 1996 championship, won by Toronto over Edmonton, would be the final Grey Cup.<ref name="BNLastGC" />
While the league struggled, the Grey Cup game itself retained its popularity and remained a national institution.<ref>{{citation |last=Zelkovich |first=Chris |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/427153401.html?FMT=ABS |title=Grey Cup a special affair; More Canadians will tune in game than any other sports event |work=Toronto Star |date=2000-11-25 |access-date=2012-08-13}}</ref> The strength of the contest allowed the league to endure its challenges.<ref name="Survival">{{citation |last=Cox |first=Damien |url=https://www.thestar.com/article/542273 |title=Grey Cup game a dud. But it doesn't matter |work=Toronto Star |date=2008-11-24 |access-date=2012-08-13}}</ref> The CFL survived into 1997 and was buoyed by an interest-free loan from the NFL,<ref>{{citation |last=Lefko |first=Perry |url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/football/cfl/lefko-bills-nfl-initiative/ |title=Bills' plan exposes NFL-CFL relationship |publisher=Sportsnet |date=2009-09-15 |access-date=2018-02-12}}</ref> a new television deal with [[The Sports Network]] which, along with the launch of its popular ''Friday Night Football'' program, has been credited with saving the league.<ref>{{citation |last=Sekeres |first=Matthew |url=https://nationalpost.com/news/toronto/story.html?id=2e965144-6cd9-4f28-976e-43d4c46c53d6&p=3 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130129202316/http://www.nationalpost.com/news/toronto/story.html?id=2e965144-6cd9-4f28-976e-43d4c46c53d6&p=3 |url-status=dead |archive-date=2013-01-29 |title=The CFL's playmakers |work=National Post |access-date=2012-07-06 }}</ref> [[85th Grey Cup|That year's]] Grey Cup, held in Edmonton and won by Toronto, drew nearly 22,000 more fans than the previous year.<ref name="GreyCupRecords" /> The CFL restored its reputation over time, enjoying new popularity into the 2000s such that it no longer had to rely on an exciting Grey Cup final to achieve stability for the next season.<ref name="Survival" />
In [[88th Grey Cup|2000]], the 8–10 BC Lions made history when they defeated the Montreal Alouettes, 28–26, becoming the first team in history to win the Grey Cup with a losing record in the regular season. In the game, 25-year veteran [[Lui Passaglia]] ended the longest career in CFL history by kicking what was ultimately the game-winning field goal.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2002/11/07/2000gc021107.html |title=2000 Grey Cup classic |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=2002-11-08 |access-date=2012-07-06}}</ref> The Calgary Stampeders matched the Lions' feat [[89th Grey Cup|the next year]] by becoming the second 8–10 team to win the Grey Cup, defeating the Winnipeg Blue Bombers by a 27–19 score in front of 65,255 fans, the second largest crowd in the game's history.<ref>{{citation |url=http://greycup.cfl.ca/2001gc |title=Grey Cup 2001 |publisher=Canadian Football League |access-date=2012-07-06 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512150453/http://greycup.cfl.ca/2001gc |archive-date=2012-05-12 }}</ref>
The [[93rd Grey Cup|2005 Grey Cup]] was the second overtime game in Grey Cup history, and the first one using the league's shootout overtime format (introduced in 2000). Both the Eskimos and Alouettes scored touchdowns on their first possessions, while Edmonton scored a field goal in its second and held Montreal scoreless to win the game by a 38–35 score.<ref name="2006TenGreatest" /> The game was played in the middle of a stretch of eight Grey Cup appearances by the Alouettes between 2000 and 2010.<ref name="GreyCupRecords" /> In [[97th Grey Cup|2009]], they defeated the Roughriders in dramatic fashion: placekicker [[Damon Duval]] missed a last-second field goal attempt that appeared to give Saskatchewan the victory. However, the Riders were penalized for having [[too many men]] on the field, allowing Duval a second opportunity. His second attempt was successful, giving Montreal a 28–27 victory.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.tsn.ca/cfl/story/?id=300347 |title=Alouettes capitalize on Riders' penalty to win 97th Grey Cup |publisher=The Sports Network |date=2009-11-30 |access-date=2012-07-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110910200930/http://www.tsn.ca/cfl/story/?id=300347 |archive-date=2011-09-10 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
The [[100th Grey Cup]] game was played on November 25, 2012, at the [[Rogers Centre]] in Toronto between the Toronto Argonauts and the Calgary Stampeders. The Toronto Argonauts won the Grey Cup with a score of 35–22.<ref name="100thGChost">{{citation |url=https://www.cfl.ca/article/100th-grey-cup-coming-to-toronto-in-2012 |title=100th Grey Cup coming to Toronto in 2012 |publisher=Canadian Football League |date=2010-06-11 |access-date=2012-07-06 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120615063124/http://cfl.ca/article/100th-grey-cup-coming-to-toronto-in-2012 |archive-date=2012-06-15 }}</ref>
As per a new title sponsorship deal with [[Shaw Communications]] announced in May 2015, the event was thenceforth known as the '''Grey Cup presented by Shaw'''.<ref name="global-shawgreycupdeal">{{cite news|title=Shaw, CFL announce Grey Cup sponsorship deal|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/1988297/shaw-cfl-announce-grey-cup-sponsorship-deal/|access-date=2 October 2015|work=Global News|publisher=Shaw Media|date=May 8, 2015}}</ref>
The [[104th Grey Cup]] game was played at [[BMO Field]] in Toronto, which became the new home of the Argonauts beginning in the 2016 season.<ref name="cfl-greycup104">{{cite news|title=104th Grey Cup presented by Shaw awarded to Toronto|url=https://www.cfl.ca/article/104th-grey-cup-presented-by-shaw-awarded-to-toronto|access-date=2 October 2015|work=CFL.ca|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151002054518/http://www.cfl.ca/article/104th-grey-cup-presented-by-shaw-awarded-to-toronto|archive-date=2 October 2015}}</ref> After being promised the [[102nd Grey Cup]] game as an incentive to rejoin the league, the [[105th Grey Cup]] game was played at [[TD Place Stadium]] in Ottawa in 2017, as part of [[150th anniversary of Canada|celebrations]] to mark 150 years of [[Canadian Confederation|Confederation]].<ref name="105-Ottawa-150">{{cite news |url=https://www.cfl.ca/2016/07/31/ottawa-host-105th-grey-cup-2017/ |title=Ottawa to host 105th Grey Cup in 2017 |publisher=Canadian Football League |date=31 July 2016 |access-date=31 July 2016}}</ref> The [[55th Grey Cup]], played at the end of the [[1967 CFL season]], was also held in Ottawa as part of [[Canadian Centennial|celebrations]] to mark 100 years of Confederation.
In May 2020, due to postponement of the regular season and other factors relating to the [[COVID-19 pandemic]], it was announced that the [[108th Grey Cup]] festivities in [[Regina, Saskatchewan]] (which were to be the first to be hosted by the new [[Mosaic Stadium]]) had been cancelled and postponed to 2022, and that the site of the game, if held, would be based on regular season records rather than as a [[Home advantage#Neutral venues|neutral site]].<ref name="cbc.ca">{{Cite web|title=CFL eyes September return, changes Grey Cup format|url=https://www.cbc.ca/sports/football/cfl/cfl-eyes-september-return-1.5577178|date=2020-05-20|website=CBC News|access-date=2020-05-20}}</ref> The Grey Cup itself was later cancelled in August along with the [[2020 CFL season]], which was the first year that the Grey Cup was not contested since 1919.
==Trophy== [[File:1909 Grey Cup Champions.jpg|thumb|left|1909 Varsity Blues, inaugural champions. The Grey Cup is pictured at the front right.|alt=Twenty-five men, divided into three rows, pose. The majority are wearing football uniforms, except for four executives in suits. Two trophies are placed in front of the players.]] The trophy was commissioned in 1909 at a cost of $48.<ref name="CFHOF" /> The [[chalice]] is made of [[sterling silver]] and stands {{convert|33|cm|in}} tall.<ref name="GreyCupFacts">{{citation |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/baltsun/access/111932360.html?dids=111932360:111932360&FMT=ABS |title=The Grey Cup |work=Baltimore Sun |date=1994-11-27 |access-date=2012-07-16 |page=6D}}</ref> Its original base was made of wood, with silver shields listing each championship year and winning team's name, beginning with the University of Toronto Varsity Blues.<ref name="Theile4" /> The players of the 1915 championship Hamilton team, apparently as revenge for Toronto's refusal to relinquish the trophy in 1912 and 1913, added a shield for the 1908 Tigers team to give the appearance that their organization had won the first Grey Cup.<ref>{{harvnb|Theile|1997|pp=3–4}}</ref>
A 1947 fire destroyed the clubhouse of the Toronto [[Argonaut Rowing Club]] and damaged the Grey Cup.<ref>{{citation |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DTNkAAAAIBAJ&pg=4061,2547028 |title=Fire destroys Argonaut club |work=Calgary Herald |date=1947-03-25 |access-date=2012-07-09 |page=15}}</ref> Many other trophies and artifacts in the clubhouse melted or were damaged beyond repair but the Grey Cup survived by catching onto a nail attached to a surviving wall when the shelf upon which it sat collapsed.<ref name="Theile4" /> The trophy has been broken on six other occasions: in 1978, when it was dropped by celebrating Edmonton Eskimos players; in 1987, when an Eskimos' player sat on it; in 1993, when Edmonton's [[Blake Dermott]] head-butted it; in 2006, when the chalice broke away from its base as the BC Lions celebrated their victory; in 2012 when one of the handles broke off as the Toronto Argonauts celebrated; in 2014 when the chalice broke away from its base again as the Calgary Stampeders celebrated their win.<ref name="LFPTrivia" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/victoriatimescolonist/news/story.html?id=0a581c25-84b7-4b39-a931-d6147f47273f |title=Why does the Grey Cup keep breaking? Calgary Stampeders damage trophy during celebrations |work=Canadian Press |publisher=National Post |date=2014-11-30 |access-date=2014-12-01 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304221702/http://www.canada.com/victoriatimescolonist/news/story.html?id=0a581c25-84b7-4b39-a931-d6147f47273f |archive-date=2016-03-04 }}</ref> The CFL commissioned a replica of the trophy in 2008.<ref>{{citation |last=Watts |first=Richard |url=http://www.canada.com/victoriatimescolonist/news/story.html?id=0a581c25-84b7-4b39-a931-d6147f47273f |title=Engraver fashions copy of Cup |work=Victoria Times-Colonist |date=2008-08-02 |access-date=2012-07-09 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109121411/http://www.canada.com/victoriatimescolonist/news/story.html?id=0a581c25-84b7-4b39-a931-d6147f47273f |archive-date=2012-11-09 }}</ref>
The Grey Cup has been stolen on two occasions: it disappeared for three days in 1967 when it was taken from the Hamilton Tiger-Cats as a prank, and in December 1969 it was stolen from the offices of the Ottawa Rough Riders at [[Lansdowne Park]].<ref>{{citation |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GWlkAAAAIBAJ&pg=1094,2599376 |title=Police continuing search for Grey Cup |work=Calgary Herald |date=1969-12-22 |access-date=2012-07-10 |page=25}}</ref> The thieves attempted to ransom the trophy, but the CFL refused to pay and made plans to replace it with a duplicate.<ref>{{citation |last=Palmer |first=Jesse |url=http://www.cbc.ca/strombo/canada/something-you-might-not-know-about-canada-the-stolen-grey-cup.html |title=Something you didn't know about Canada: The stolen Grey Cup |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=2012-01-11 |access-date=2012-07-10}}</ref> An anonymous phone call led to the trophy's recovery two months later in a locker at Toronto's [[Fairmont Royal York|Royal York Hotel]].<ref>{{citation |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=34EuAAAAIBAJ&pg=4439,4263453 |title=Grey Cup found |work=Montreal Gazette |date=1970-02-17 |access-date=2012-07-10 |page=9}}</ref> The thieves were never found.<ref>{{citation |last=Hopper |first=Tristin |url=http://sports.nationalpost.com/2012/06/26/grey-cup-to-tour-canada-on-specialized-12-car-train-for-74-day-whistle-stop-tour/ |title=Grey Cup to tour Canada on specialized 12-car train for 74-day whistle-stop tour |work=National Post |date=2012-06-26 |access-date=2012-07-10 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130129175131/http://sports.nationalpost.com/2012/06/26/grey-cup-to-tour-canada-on-specialized-12-car-train-for-74-day-whistle-stop-tour/ |archive-date=2013-01-29 }}</ref>
[[File:Montreal Jojuan Armour.jpg|thumb|right|Calgary's [[JoJuan Armour]] celebrates his team's 2008 championship.|alt=A player in a white uniform with red trim and a black number 2 on his chest raises a large silver trophy over his head.]] The current design of the Grey Cup's base was introduced in 1987, coinciding with the 75th anniversary of the first Grey Cup championship.<ref name="1987Base">{{citation |last=Boswell |first=Randy |url=http://www2.canada.com/sports/grey+tradition+peril+players/4905204/story.html?id=4905204 |title=Grey Cup tradition at peril for players |work=Ottawa Citizen |date=2011-06-07 |access-date=2012-07-10 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203023315/http://www2.canada.com/sports/grey+tradition+peril+players/4905204/story.html?id=4905204 |archive-date=2013-12-03 }}</ref> The base stands {{convert|84|cm|in}} high and is made of black-lacquered aluminum with silver plates engraved with the names of each winning team's players and executives since 1909.<ref name="GreyCupFacts" /><ref name="1987Base" /> The trophy, one of Canada's best known symbols, ran out of room for new additions following the [[100th Grey Cup|2012 Grey Cup]]. The league announced that the base would be redesigned but remain similar in shape to its current design.<ref>{{citation |last=Masters |first=Mark |url=http://sports.nationalpost.com/2011/05/31/grey-cup-to-be-redesigned-after-2012-season/ |title=Grey Cup to be redesigned after 2012 season |work=National Post |date=2011-05-31 |access-date=2012-07-10 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130129132623/http://sports.nationalpost.com/2011/05/31/grey-cup-to-be-redesigned-after-2012-season/ |archive-date=2013-01-29 }}</ref> In 2020 the new base required the removal of the 1909 plaque.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tsn.ca/grey-cup-gets-new-base-for-3rd-time-in-history-1.1300214 |title=Grey Cup gets new base for 3rd time in history |work=TSN |agency=Canadian Press |date=May 3, 2019 |access-date=July 7, 2021 }}</ref> To accommodate all the plaques within the base of the Grey Cup, they were redesigned using laser etching and a modern typeface that allowed for vertical reduction of the characters and letters that had improved legibility. The trophy is customarily escorted to the new champions by two members of the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] and presented by the commissioner of the CFL.
Similar to the more famous [[Stanley Cup]] used exclusively today by the NHL, members of the winning teams are allowed time to celebrate with the trophy in their own fashion, often taking it to their home towns or tours in locations across Canada.<ref>{{citation |last=Beamish |first=Mike |title=Mr. Grey goes where no Cup has gone before |work=Vancouver Sun |date=2012-06-27}}</ref> The board of directors for the [[Canadian Football Hall of Fame]] act as the Grey Cup's trustees and control its rental for events. The trophy is accompanied by a designated representative of the Hall of Fame at all times.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cfhof.ca/uploads/assets/cflhof/Forms/Grey_Cup_Policy_Third_Party_Eng.pdf |title=Policy for rental of the Grey Cup trophy |publisher=Canadian Football Hall of Fame and Museum |access-date=2012-07-10 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120706170944/http://www.cfhof.ca/uploads/assets/cflhof/Forms/Grey_Cup_Policy_Third_Party_Eng.pdf |archive-date=2012-07-06 }}</ref> Like the Stanley Cup, but unlike the [[Vince Lombardi Trophy]] for the NFL's Super Bowl, a new trophy is not made every year for the winning team to keep; rather, the Grey Cup is loaned to the winning team for a year.
==Languages== English and French are the official languages of the game.
==Grey Cup festival== Each year, the host city organizes numerous events as part of the annual Grey Cup festival. Gala concerts, parties, and fan festivals are held in the days leading up to the championship game.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.tsn.ca/cfl/story/?id=290364 |title=Grey Cup Festival organizers announce musical lineup |publisher=The Sports Network |date=2009-09-08 |access-date=2012-07-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100324092743/http://www.tsn.ca/cfl/story/?id=290364 |archive-date=2010-03-24 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The CFL hands out its annual awards during the festival, and an annual Grey Cup parade is held. Historically, the festival also featured the "Miss Grey Cup" beauty pageant; this was discontinued in 1992.<ref>{{citation |last=McMahon |first=Tom |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6yAyAAAAIBAJ&pg=3025,1830179 |title=The selling of Canadian football: There's more to it than the Grey Cup |work=Montreal Gazette |date=1985-11-23 |access-date=2012-07-07}}</ref> The game itself includes a performance of the [[O Canada|Canadian national anthem]] (usually sung in both English and French, the official languages of the game) and a [[List of Grey Cup Halftime Performances|halftime show]], often featuring performances by well-known Canadian musical acts such as [[Nickelback]], who performed at the 2011 game.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.tsn.ca/cfl/story/?id=379692 |title=Nickelback to perform during Grey Cup halftime show |publisher=The Sports Network |date=2011-11-05 |access-date=2012-08-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111107161846/http://www.tsn.ca/cfl/story/?id=379692 |archive-date=2011-11-07 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The coin toss was usually presented by a former football player or a special guest to recognize their community involvement or significance.
Nicknamed Canada's "Grand National Drunk",<ref name="WFPMoments">{{citation |last=Tait |first=Ed |url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/opinion/columnists/grey-cup-moments-that-stick-77048837.html |title=Grey Cup moments that stick |work=Winnipeg Free Press |date=2009-11-28 |access-date=2012-07-07 |page=D1}}</ref> the Grey Cup party originated in the [[36th Grey Cup|1948 championship]] when hundreds of Calgary Stampeders fans descended on Toronto for their team's first appearance in the game.<ref>{{citation |last=Jones |first=Terry |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Football/CFL/GreyCup/2010/11/24/16297266.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130115102639/http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Football/CFL/GreyCup/2010/11/24/16297266.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 15, 2013 |title=Big Game ... Big Country |work=Edmonton Sun |date=2010-11-24 |access-date=2012-07-07 }}</ref> Bringing [[chuckwagon]]s and horses, the fans organized a pancake breakfast – a staple of the [[Calgary Stampede]] – for bewildered Torontonians. According to historian [[Hugh Dempsey]], "The Grey Cup was just another game until Calgary went down to Toronto with chuckwagons and everything and turned it into an event."<ref>{{citation |last=Bly |first=David |title=When Stamps changed the game forever |work=Calgary Herald |date=2001-11-24 |page=A3}}</ref> The Stampeders won the game on the strength of the "sleeper play", a touchdown scored by [[Norm Hill]] after he hid himself from the Ottawa defence by lying down on the sidelines, as if asleep. He received the pass from quarterback [[Keith Spaith]] while still on his back.<ref>{{citation|last=Christie |first=Alan |url=http://greycup.cfl.ca/article/the-story-of-the-1948-grey-cup_43629 |title=The Story of the 1948 Grey Cup |publisher=Canadian Football League |date=2008-10-26 |access-date=2012-07-07 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005064722/http://greycup.cfl.ca/article/the-story-of-the-1948-grey-cup_43629 |archive-date=2011-10-05 }}</ref> The victory completed the only undefeated season in the history of Canadian professional football.<ref>{{citation |last=Rhoden |first=William C. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/20/sports/football/20rhoden.html |title=Saints Won't Go 16–0, but That Was Never the Goal |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2009-12-20 |access-date=2012-07-07}}</ref> The boisterous celebrations that followed the win gave rise to the legend of Calgary alderman and future mayor [[Donald Hugh Mackay|Don Mackay]] riding his horse into the lobby of the Royal York Hotel.<ref>{{citation |last=Perkins |first=Dave |url=https://www.thestar.com/article/278426 |title=Mud slides, horse rides and frolic |work=Toronto Star |date=2007-11-22 |access-date=2012-07-07}}</ref> This event was repeated in the 2012 Grey Cup game in Toronto to much of the delight of the fans of both teams. The Calgary Grey Cup Committee maintains the tradition of organizing a pancake breakfast at each year's championship.<ref>{{citation |last=Wood |first=Damien |url=http://www.calgarysun.com/2011/11/20/calgary-grey-cup-committee-gears-up-for-vancouver-road-trip |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130118160957/http://www.calgarysun.com/2011/11/20/calgary-grey-cup-committee-gears-up-for-vancouver-road-trip |url-status=dead |archive-date=2013-01-18 |title=Calgary Grey Cup committee gears up for Vancouver road trip |work=Calgary Sun |date=2011-11-20 |access-date=2012-07-07 }}</ref>
A 2012 survey found that Canadians consider the Grey Cup to be the most important annual event to attend.<ref name="MostImportant">{{citation |last=Johnstone |first=Bruce |url=http://www2.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/business_agriculture/story.html?id=6ed9e66a-5c8c-4756-8b7e-361ab1e70ef4 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130118210154/http://www2.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/business_agriculture/story.html?id=6ed9e66a-5c8c-4756-8b7e-361ab1e70ef4 |url-status=dead |archive-date=2013-01-18 |title=Grey Cup's $123M touchdown |work=Regina Leader-post |date=2012-06-30 |access-date=2012-11-13 }}</ref> Fans of all teams converge at the game venue,<ref name="WFPMoments" /> including some who have attended 60 or more Grey Cups.<ref>{{citation |last=Platt |first=Michael |url=http://www.calgarysun.com/news/columnists/michael_platt/2009/11/25/11917246-sun.html |title=Fan to take in 64th final |work=Calgary Sun |date=2009-11-25 |access-date=2012-07-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106112252/http://www.calgarysun.com/news/columnists/michael_platt/2009/11/25/11917246-sun.html |archive-date=2010-01-06 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The influx of people from across the country is estimated to have an economic impact of over $120 million for the region hosting the championship game.<ref name="MostImportant" />
==Champions== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left; margin-left:1em; float:right" |- |+ Grey Cup appearances, active teams<ref name="GreyCupRecords" /> |- ! Team ! Wins ! Losses ! Total ! Last Won |- | [[Toronto Argonauts]] || 17 || 6 || 23 || 2017 |- | [[Edmonton Elks]] || 14 || 9 || 23 || 2015 |- | [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]] || 12 || 14 || 26 || 2021 |- | [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] || 8 || 14 || 22 || 1999 |- | [[Calgary Stampeders]] || 8 || 9 || 17 || 2018 |- | [[Montreal Alouettes]] || 7 || 11 || 18 || 2010 |- | [[BC Lions]] || 6 || 4 || 10 || 2011 |- | [[Saskatchewan Roughriders]] || 4 || 15 || 19 || 2013 |- | [[Ottawa Redblacks]] || 1 || 2 || 3 || 2016 |} {{Main|List of Grey Cup champions}} The Toronto Argonauts have won the most Grey Cup championships (17), followed by the Edmonton Eskimos (now Elks) (14) and Winnipeg Blue Bombers (12).<ref name="LFPTrivia">{{citation |url=https://lfpress.com/sports/football/2010/11/25/16328326.html |title=Grey Cup trivia |work=London Free Press |date=2010-11-28 |access-date=2012-07-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202224210/http://www.lfpress.com/sports/football/2010/11/25/16328326.html |archive-date=2013-12-02 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]] have made the most Grey Cup appearances (26).<ref name="GreyCupRecords" /> Since the merger and creation of the Canadian Football League began in 1958, the Eskimos have won the most Grey Cup Championships (11) and have made the most Grey Cup appearances (19). The Saskatchewan Roughriders have the most losses in Grey Cup play (15), including five consecutive losses between 1928 and 1932.<ref name="LFPTrivia" /> The defending champions are the Winnipeg Blue Bombers who won the [[108th Grey Cup]] in 2021, their second consecutive title. Six teams in CFL history have won the Grey Cup at home, the 2013 Saskatchewan Roughriders, the 2012 Toronto Argonauts, the 2011 BC Lions, the 1994 BC Lions, the 1977 Montreal Alouettes, and 1972 Hamilton Tiger-Cats.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/football/cfl/story/2011/11/27/sp-blue-bombers-lions-grey-cup.html |title=Lulay leads Lions to Grey Cup victory over Bombers |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=2011-11-27}}</ref>
Individually, three players have won seven Grey Cups: [[Jack Wedley]] (Toronto, Montreal Navy), [[Bill Stevenson (offensive lineman)|Bill Stevenson]] (Edmonton) and [[Hank Ilesic]] (Edmonton, Toronto). Ilesic is one of seven players to appear in nine Grey Cup games. Among quarterbacks, [[Anthony Calvillo]] appeared in a record eight games, winning three.<ref name="GreyCupRecords" /> Five coaches share the record for Grey Cup championships at five: [[Wally Buono]] (the CFL's all-time leader in total games won), [[Don Matthews]], [[Frank Clair]], [[Hugh Campbell]] and [[Lew Hayman]].<ref>{{citation |last=Wazny |first=Adam |title=Lions loaded with Grey Cup experience |work=Winnipeg Free Press |date=2011-11-27}}</ref><ref>{{citation |last=Willes |first=Ed |url=http://www.canada.com/sports/football/Willes+Wally+Buono+begins+life+away+from+Lions+sidelines/6717705/story.html |title=Wally Buono begins new life away from Lions' sidelines |work=Vancouver Province |date=2012-06-01 |access-date=2012-07-08 }}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Two individual awards are handed out following each game. The [[Grey Cup Most Valuable Player|Most Valuable Player]] award is given to the top performer in the Grey Cup. Between 1974 and 1990, the league named both offensive and defensive most valuable players. Three people have been named MVP on three occasions: [[Doug Flutie]], [[Damon Allen]] and [[Sonny Wade]].<ref name="GreyCupRecords" /> The [[Dick Suderman Trophy]] is given to the most valuable Canadian. It is named in honour of [[Dick Suderman]], who died of a brain hemorrhage in 1972 while an active player for the Edmonton Eskimos.<ref>{{citation |last=Fathers |first=Ken |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wDM_AAAAIBAJ&pg=2112,4361488 |title=A just reward |work=The Windsor Star |date=1972-12-04 |access-date=2012-07-16 |page=26}}</ref> [[Dave Sapunjis]] and [[Don Sweet]] have each won the award three times (however, Sapunjis is the only player to win the award in back-to-back years).<ref name="GreyCupRecords" /> [[Andrew Harris (Canadian football)|Andrew Harris]] was the first person to win both awards in the [[107th Grey Cup]] for the [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]].
==Venue== ===Host cities=== The city of Toronto has hosted the most Grey Cup games with 48, including 30 of the first 45 games played.<ref name="GreyCupRecords" /> The first game was held on December 4, 1909, at [[Rosedale Field]].<ref name="Theile13" /> Hamilton and Ottawa hosted several early games while Sarnia and Kingston each hosted one as the game's early years were dominated by teams in southern Ontario.<ref name="GreyCupRecords" /> The Grey Cup game and champion first left the province in 1931, when Montreal hosted the event and the [[Montreal AAA Winged Wheelers]] won the [[19th Grey Cup]].<ref>{{citation |url=http://greycup.cfl.ca/1931gc |title=Grey Cup 1931 |publisher=Canadian Football League |access-date=2012-07-07 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512152606/http://greycup.cfl.ca/1931gc |archive-date=2012-05-12 }}</ref> The game did not leave central Canada until 1955 when the [[43rd Grey Cup]] was played in Vancouver.<ref>{{citation |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HD5lAAAAIBAJ&pg=1129,4848895 |title=Grey Cup final crowns city's great surge in sports |work=Vancouver Sun |date=1955-11-25 |access-date=2012-07-07 |page=6}}</ref> That contest achieved what was at the time an all-time Canadian football attendance record of 39,491.<ref>{{citation |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dz5kAAAAIBAJ&pg=3855,2109945 |title=Grey Cup contest breaks all marks |work=Calgary Herald |date=1956-01-13 |access-date=2012-08-14 |page=36}}</ref> It was the first of 16 games hosted by the British Columbia city, second among all host cities.<ref name="GreyCupRecords" />
The four highest attended Grey Cup games have been held at the [[Olympic Stadium (Montreal)|Olympic Stadium]] in Montreal,<ref name="GreyCupRecords" /> with an all-time record of 68,318 set in 1977.<ref name="Gazette1986History" />
